body:
@caarlos0 I'm afraid we can't really enforce it. All we can do is having one place and point to it whenever we see a not so nice commit message.

Should we just go with the same conventions as Hugo or do you have any other preferences?
@caarlos0 nice! That looks way better! Can give it a try. I can do the setup if you like.

Yeah, feel free to do it üó° 

I saw it here: https://github.com/pagarme/pilot/pull/187#issuecomment-324526348

It's in portuguese, but basically, the action should either be add, remove, refactor, move, bump, update or release, which I think is fine, if agree we can copy it =D

@caarlos0 I cannot add the webhook. 
Could you add https://hooks.gitcop.com/github
here: https://github.com/goreleaser/goreleaser/settings/hooks/new 
Also need a secret. I'll send it to you in Slack ok?

It is set up. I merged their suggested list with the one you listed above @caarlos0.
Now looks like this:
![screen shot 2017-10-01 at 19 54 26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/738978/31057411-8331a9a2-a6e2-11e7-8efe-cae1a6622f25.png)
I will also add this to CONTRIBUTING.md

issue.title: docs: Add commit message guidelines to CONTRIBUTING.md
issue.body:
Explain contributors how to craft useful commit messages.
We also use https://gitcop.com/ to enforce the formatting.

Closes #377

issue.title: Inject binary into dockerfile
issue.body:
* allow env vars for `archive.name_template`
* inject binary filename into `Dockerfile`

Let me provide some background for this PR and if you agree with the approach then I'll add tests and update the documentation.

I want to use goreleaser to release https://github.com/fabiolb/fabio. I have some special requirements for naming and packaging most of which were already supported by goreleaser. At this point I don't want to change the naming of the artifacts since this would break the debian/ubuntu packages that people are building and which they have automated. 

For fabio I need to publish releases with the binary artifacts for multiple platforms with the following names:

```
fabio-VERSION-go1.x.x-GOOS_GOARCH
fabio-1.5.3-go1.9.2-linux_amd64
```

I also need to publish Docker containers which contain the go version in the tag since I sometimes publish the current version built with a newer go version, e.g.

```
fabiolb/fabio:1.5.3-go1.8.5
fabiolb/fabio:1.5.3-go1.9.2
```

#437 added support for the env vars in the Docker tags which allows me to inject the go version into the Docker tags.

This change now adds support for env vars in the `name_template` so that I can build artifacts with the go version. 

```yaml
archive:
  name_template: '{{ .ProjectName }}-{{ .Version }}-{{ .Env.GOVERSION }}-{{ .Os }}_{{ .Arch }}'
  format: binary
```

However, that breaks the generation of the Docker container since the name of the binary is no longer known upfront in a static Dockerfile. `COPY fabio /` no longer works since the binary is now `fabio-1.5.3-go1.9.2-linux_amd64`. 

The Dockerfile has an `ENV` directive which allows for some templating but I couldn't figure out how to overwrite the ENV variable from the command line with `docker build`. If that is possible then the change becomes much simpler and works outside of goreleaser as well and I would actually prefer that. (https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/#environment-replacement)

The approach in this PR is to copy the Dockerfile and expand the `${BINARY}` variable in the `Dockerfile` to the true filename of the artifact. Then you can write something like this:

```
FROM scratch
ENV BINARY fabio
COPY ${BINARY} /fabio
ENTRYPOINT ["/fabio"]
```

## Types of changes

<!--- What types of changes does your code introduce? Put an `x` in all the boxes that apply: -->

- [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change)
- [x] I have read the **CONTRIBUTING** document.
- [ ] `make ci` passes on my machine.
- [x] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [ ] I have added tests to cover my changes.
